 1. SECTOR BACKGROUND A. COUNTRY BACKGROUND 1.1 Lesotho is a poor, mountainous and landlocked country, completely surrounded by the Republic of South Africa (RSA). Lesotho has been historically described as a "labor reserve" for South Africa's mines. About one half of those who are formally employed work in the mines of South Africa and one third of gross national product (GNP) is accounted for by migrant miners' remittances. However, formal employment constitutes only 28 percent of total employment in the country, and 72 percent of the labor force is engaged in agriculture and the informal sector at implicit wages that are typically below the poverty line. The 1994 Poverty Assessment study shows continuing high levels of relative poverty (50 percent) and unemployment, principally as a result of the loss of employment opportunities for Basotho workers in South Africa's mining industry. Those are a major cause for concern to the Government, which is committed to poverty alleviation and has developed a strategy, the objectives of which are to: (i) create jobs; and (ii) generate growth in the economy. A key aspect to achieve these objectives relies on the shift of the public works program towards labor-based methods. Another key aspect is to provide access to isolated areas poorly served by the current road network through instating maintenance and improving road conditions to all-year round serviceability. 1.2 Despite a growth of about 15 percent per year in the export sector, and 10% gross domestic product (GDP) growth rates, no substantial unemployment reduction has occurred. Agriculture, including animal husbandry, which contributes at least partially to the income and employment of approximately 70 percent of all households, accounts for only 15 percent of GDP. Manufacturing and construction continue to grow and make up about 36 percent of GDP. There is significant new employment in garment manufacturing for export, and good prospects for further employment growth in this sector. Commerce and government, however, remain the largest contributors to GDP, with Government services (including the commercial parastatals) accounting for almost half of the production of this sector. Although equitable, broad-based growth of the economy will depend on both the agricultural and industrial sectors, since agriculture has limited capacity to absorb excess labor, growth will have to be led by the private commercial and industrial sectors. Approximately one half of the government revenue comes from Lesotho's share of import tariffs collected by the Southern Africa Custom Union (SACU).
 1.3 By the mid- 1980s, the Government of Lesotho (GOL) realized that its former policy of aiming for economic self-sufficiency by following a parastatal-led, import- substitution strategy was unsustainable. An alarming fiscal deficit induced the Govermment to develop in 1988, with the assistance from the World Bank and the IMF, a strategy aimed at stabilizing the economy. The main objectives of the structural adjustment program were to strengthen fiscal discipline, diversify the country's export base, and improve social services. Following a period of slow growth in real GDP in the first half of the 1980s (averaging 1.7 percent a year), real GDP grew considerably between 1988 to 1994, achieving an average annual growth rate of 8.5 percent. This growth was due in large part to a 16 percent growth rate of manufacturing and construction, including in particular activities within the Lesotho Highlands Water Project (LHWP), which counterbalanced the effects of two drought years and a decline in mineworkers remittances. In 1994, GNP per capita was US$700 in current Dollar terms. In addition substantial progress has been made in controlling expenditures and putting in place revenue enhancement measures. The fiscal deficit of 9 percent of GNP in 1988/89 was reversed to a small fiscal surplus by 1992/93. Currently, thc government is a net repayer to the banking system, removing earlier concerns that bank financing would not be available to the private sector. 1.4 However, during this period of stabilization, implementation of structural reforms has been slow, in particular in civil service capacity-building, which threatens achievements of the adjustment program. A fifth five-year development plan has been elaborated for the years 1991/1996. Its four overarching objectives are: (i) economic recovery and sustainable growth to provide the population with a better access to basic services; (ii) creation of an enabling environment to facilitate the role of the private sector in delivering services, with special reference to the development of a private construction industry, and privatization or restructuring of public enterprises and parastatals; and (iii) removal of capacity constraints in the public sector, and decentralization, which has recently led to the first democratic election of Village District Councils (VDCs). The recent three-year Policy Framework Paper, supported by an IMF-financed 12-month stand-by arrangement, recommends to accelerate the creation of a better investmen. climate for foreign capital, increase the pace of privatization, and not maintain fiscal surpluses by under-investing in infrastructure and human capital. 1.5 The Government's infrastructure strategy focuses on poverty reduction and employment creation through the expansion of labor-based public works, improving the coverage and quality of basic services, increasing the role of the private sector in the delivery of basic infrastructure services, privatizing public enterprises and parastatals, and removing capacity constraints in the public sector. It emphasizes (i) increasing the role of the private sector; (ii) capacity building and investment in human resources; and (iii) improved cost recovery of services, and a better balanced and increased overall level of recurrent and investment expenditures. Currently, the implementation of the Govermment's infrastructure strategy is constrained by limited line ministerial capacity in planning, accounting and management, and the excessive reliance on force account arrangements for providing services. Civil service reform, and support to the
 - 3 - development of the private sector and privatization of those activities that can be best performed by the private sector, are central to the improvement of the efficiency and management of public utilities and services. 1.6 The Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for Lesotho emphasizes the direct and indirect poverty-reducing effects of expanding and improving rural and peri-urban infrastructure, and increasing the share of civil works being carried out using labor-based techniques. It supports (i) maintaining and strengthening structural reforms to create employment and improve incomes; (ii) addressing capacity constraints in the public sector through capacity building and investment in human resources, and involving communities in the development and management of services; and (iii) capturing the benefits of the LHWP, and in particular strengthening rural development through a clearer and more transparent use of the Development Fund (into which the revenues of the LHWP are being deposited. As a result of the 1994 Bank's Poverty Assessment study, a poverty reduction action plan was elaborated jointly with the Government and the Lesotho Council of NGOs. It stresses the need for a major expansion of labor-based public works, including restoring or instating the serviceability of roads to provide isolated areas with all-year round access. An improved and better balanced road network will facilitate economic development and the extension of basic social services in the remote, poor areas of the country. The Government has already acted on these recommendations, and is currently executing a major new public works initiative financed from the Revenue Fund of the Lesotho Highlands Water Project (LHWP) to the benefit of rural communities, which have overwhelmingly chosen road infrastructure as priority investments. The proposed operation would be an integral part of IDA's ongoing assistance to GOL aimed at facilitating economic development and reducing poverty by extending basic services and growth to isolated parts of the country, through financing key parts of the National Road Program and ensuring the link between village-built roads and the rest of the network. A key aspect of the proposed project is to rapidly increase the institutional capacity and substantially accelerate private sector participation in road activities, in order to effectively handle the substantially higher level of road activities. B. THE TRANSPORT SECTOR 1.7 Highly mountainous, with rugged terrain and wintery conditions in the Highlands, Lesotho depends almost exclusively on privately-operated road transport for internal transport. The country has no navigable rivers and no railway except for a short (2 kcm) rail link operated by South Africa Railways from the South African border to Maseru. Air transport by the local company Lesotho Airways accounts respectively for only 0.01% and 0.5% of freight and passenger transport. For external travel, Lesotho depends almost entirely on RSA's well developed transport system. Because of Lesotho's high proportion of migrant workers and low level of marketed domestic production, demand for passenger transport is relatively high. 1.8 The present condition of the transport infrastructure is unbalanced as a result of past investments in the transport sector in Lesotho, which have been oriented since 1967
 - 4 - towards the primary transit and import/export corridors of the lowlands serving the emerging manufacturing sector along the border with the RSA. This has led to relative neglect of the transport infrastructure to serve the transportation needs of the Lesotho population and large segments of the domestic economy. Most traffic originates and ends in the lowlands, and freight is 95% lowlands-based, with the exception of the route to the LHWP dam and transfer tunnels sites. This, and limited budget resources, has meant that Highlands have been little accounted for in the investment flow. 1.9 The great majority of road transport trips is made by private transport, and 75% of passenger transport is by privately-owned public transport. The publicly-owned Lesotho Freight and Bus Services Corporation (LFBSC) accounts for only 0.5% of total public transport. Inadequate capacity and lack of accountability of responsible government agencies (largely due to the high dependency on, and poor management of foreign technical assistance which has prevented the country from successfully developing sound institutions and retaining a cadre of skilled staff), poor cost recovery practices, and inadequate regulations of transport services, have led to deterioration of the condition of the sector. 1.10 Currently, fare levels are set by the Department of Transport and Traffic (DTT) of the Ministry of Transport and Communication (MOTC), on the basis of average vehicle operating costs (VOC) and utilization rates which are in fact not well known. This leads to distortions in the pricing structure, aggravated by the significant differential margin between lowlands and mountainous areas. They are, moreover, reviewed at irregular intervals. There is a need for reforming the fare policy to provide for stable prices set on a route by route basis, or better to leave fares to the market with an eventual passenger- protecting fare cap (with a transparent direct subsidy to the most costly routes to the isolated mountainous areas). A key issue is cost recovery of damages imposed onto roads by traffic (i.e. users of the road network), hence the need for users being charged for the costs of maintenance and rehabilitation. 1.11 The vehicle fleet is marked by a large percentage of vans and combies (about 60%) and a low percentage of trucks (10%) and buses (2.5%), and by the use of second- hand vehicles from the RSA. Passenger transport operators are mainly single vehicle operators (combies) and a few larger operators with up to 100 vehicles. LFBSC has been restructured as part of the parastatal reform process, with the freight section of the Corporation liquidated, and the bus section retained, although downsized, to serve remote areas of the country. The main issues are cumbersome permits administration and negative licensing by the Road Transport Board (RTB), which could be resolved by granting a licensing authority to the DTT while focusing the Board role on regulating the industry, and unregulated army and police vehicles used for paying passenger transport with a de facto subsidy. 1.12 The existing road safety situation is poor. Lesotho's accident rate is ranking among the highest by international standards, with a rate of fatalities per 10,000 vehicles increasing from 105 in the late eighties to 130 in the most recent years. Police enforcement with regard to moving traffic is generally complained about as unfair and
 unreasonable. Road safety measures, either active or passive, are very uncoordinated, due to the very meager resources actually spent and the fragmented responsibility between MOTC, the Ministry of Works (MOW), and the Royal Lesotho Mounted Police. 1.13 Axle load surveys conducted as part of the 1994 National Transport Study (NTS) show that multi-axle trucks account for the bulk of ESA km/year, and that about 40% of those trucks exceeded the current 8.2 tons limit. There is currently no enforcement of axle-load regulations, and the two permanent weighbridges near Maseru are not monitored. Although the mobile weighscales operated by the RB are appropriate for random checking, lay-bys are non-existent and surveys fairly unorganized. Another issue concerns the difficulty of raising the axle-load (currently set at 8 tons) to a limit closer to the recently adopted 13 tons limit in the RSA following the Southern Africa Transport and Communications Commission (SATCC) recommendations. The NTS estimated that road damage savings from setting the axle-load limit to a maximum of 10 tons would more than offset additional transport costs, as most heavy traffic is limited to lowlands corridors and access routes to LHWP sites. 1.14 GOL's Transport Sector Strategy, defined in the NTS, has four main objectives: (i) to support improved access to communities, in particular those living in isolated rural areas, and linking district towns between themselves; (ii) to implement adequate taxation of transport services; (iii) to enforce traffic control and axle-load regulations; and (iv) to strengthen institutional capacity. It emphasizes supporting: (a) reforming the policy and institutional environment, including: (i) stimulating participation of the private sector in the sector; (ii) full cost recovery (wherever possible) and adequate allowances for funding of capital investments; and (iii) coordinating policy-making, planning and usage of road transport; (b) commencing the development of the institutional, organizational and human resources capacity required to effectively plan for, and manage the road transport sector; (c) removing the limitations that the present transport infrastucture services place on economic activity, by investing in physical ifratucture rehabilitation and maintenance, focusing investment on improved access and increased transport services to mountain communities, and implementing road works through methods which favor employment. C. THE ROAD SECTOR Adminitration of Roads and Maintenance Organization 1.15 Raponsibility for the management of the road network is divided between three agencies: the Roads Branch (RB) and the Labor Construction Unit (LCU) of the Ministry of Works (MOW), and the Civil Works Section (CWS) under the Ministry of Local
 - 6 - Govement (MLG).The RB has primary overall responsibility for the classified roads, which are the most important and most heavily trafficked roads of the network, and bridges. The LCU is responsible for upgrading earth roads to engineered standards, and maintaining them using labor-based methods (involving light equipment such as pedestrian rollers, water bowsers, tractors). The CWS has responsibility for the construction and maintenance of earth tracks and one-lane earth roads. All works carried out by CWS are labor-intensive (involving mostly labor and tools), and the roads or tracks they construct are to a lower standard than LCU-built roads. The workers are paid mainly through the Food for Work Program (FWP), topped with a cash incentive, which has attracted a very high percentage of women (estimated at about 80% of the labor force in this program). Roads are selected on the basis of populations choices and commitment to provide labor. CWS' role also includes the construction of footbridges and clinics in the country's isolated areas. 1.16 The Lesotho Highlands Development Authority (LHDA) is the parastatal responsible for the LHWP, which includes the construction and operation of a series of dams, hydropower plants, transfer tunnels and pump houses to transfer water to the Vaal River Basin in the RSA. Incidental to these massive hydraulic works there has been, and will continue to be, a need to construct and strengthen access roads to the dam sites. Tlhus the LHDA, which is not a road agency, has de facto temporary responsibility for certain road links, including the construction of minor village and district roads. It has been agreed, and this is Government's policy, that maintenance responsibility for the roads which are currently under the LHDA administration, should be devolved to the Roads Branch. The larger issue of maintenance responsibility for different categories of roads will be addressed under the Project. 1.17 The management of urban roads has long been a difficult responsibility and financing issue. The experience with the only independent local government, Maseru City Council (MCC), showed that limited local financial and technical capacity resulted in poor maintenance of urban streets. The institutional arrangements and the nature of the works to be undertaken in or around Maseru (and their financial implications) need to be agreed upon by all stakeholders on the basis of the expected increase in truck traffic from (i) the construction of the Mohale dam and other works under Phase 1B of the LHWP; and (ii) traffic generated by the construction of a new bridge at the border in Maseru. This issue requires to be tackled within the context of the current decentralization effort, and will be partly addressed under this project through the rehabilitation of main corridor routes around Maseru, and the eligibility of urban roads for financing from the Road Fund on a cost-sharing basis. 1.18 The road management structure is split between two Ministries (MOW and MLG), not counting LHDA (under the Ministry of Natural Resources) which has specific objectives. The analysis of the organization charts for the RB and the current rural roads organization (LCU and CWS) clearly shows that the road institutional structure is uncoordinated, in particular with regard to planning/programming, and operations almost fully independent. The present road classification system is less than ideal from a functional point of view, and road management, due to its fragmentation between four
 - 7 - agencies and three Ministries, is hampered by unclear responsibilities over extensive parts of the network and by the fact that a great many LCU and some RB roads have never been gazetted. In addition, the classification and numbering of roads are inadequate to the evolving situation of the road network, and in particular do not allow road agencies to develop a framework to plan, design, construct and maintain their respective networks. The RB, as per the Road Act, is the road authority for all roads in Lesotho, and other road agencies are operating within a loose legal context. This has resulted in about 820 km of rural roads not falling under any agency's responsibility, which means in practice that these roads are not maintained, although CWS would have to take the responsibility. Government has agreed with the proposal made in the NTS to conduct a functional reclassification, and subsequent renumbering, of the network. In parallel, there is a need to define mechanisms to register and transfer roads, which would require a revision of the Road Act, which is no longer adequate and responsive to present requirements. 1.19 The RB and the LCU are organized as departments within the MOW, and are subject to Public Service regulations. Employment conditions are far from being competitive with those offered in the private sector or even parastatals. To address the problems raised by the fragmentation of the sector, a proposal to regroup LCU and CWS under a department of rural roads in MOW, and the restructuring of the RB with more capacity in project supervision and procurement, has been made in the NTS. This proposal does not account for the specificity of the CWS (work methods, payment, community participation) and the need for better coordination and cooperation between agencies. The project will aim to solve these organizational issues through the restructuring of MOW and regrouping of all road agencies under its authority. An amendment of the 1969 Road Act will be necessary to better reflect responsibilities. 1.20 The RB has under its wing a Road Construction Unit (RCU) and a Road Improvement Unit (RIU), which operate in a very independent and almost contractual way with separate budgets and accounts, as well as their own equipment and workshops. These units are mainly carrying out all types of work activities on gravel roads, including upgrading them to paved standards, and some minor periodic maintenance on paved roads. Other RB force account units are responsible for routine maintenance. If the maintenance situation is "acceptable" for the RB network, despite relatively high costs, in that it is mainly carried out, much of the unpaved LCU and CWS network is not well maintained. Regular routine maintenance on CWS and LCU roads has been so far given low priority, and little contracting took place despite Government stated policy of contracting out maintenance. Very little periodic maintenance activities are carried out on gravel roads, with the result that only rehabilitation on LCU gravel roads, mainly donor-funded, is undertaken. 1.21 The Government's Plant and Vehicle Pool System (PVPS), which is under the administrative control of MOW and assumes ownership of all mobile plant and vehicles, is in serious difficulty: (i) low productivity; (ii) large vehicle fleet with many unserviceable items, and scattered plant of which about 50% is not operational; (iii) lack of spare parts; (iv) poor management and accountability of the fuel services; (v) lack of trained mechanics due to uncompetitive pay scales; and (vi) very few senior management
 - 8 - staff. This results in operational inefficiencies and high costs, although hire charges are regularly revised with regard to those high costs. The policy to service all plant and vehicle services through PVPS for a 2.5% service fee (plus an extra charge of 5% when services are sub-contracted to the private sector) to cover administrative costs, is highly cost ineffective. Its enforcement since last year can only result in PVPS being more overburdened and performing its role even less efficiently and effectively, without alleviating heavy reliance on private services and facilities, in particular, across the border in RSA. The size of the government vehicle and plant fleet is in itself a powerful incentive for local garages to expand facilities. The immediate objective should be to introduce a degree of competition and restructure PVPS operations and management, and do away with equipment and plant in line with the Government strategy to contract out civil works, before PVPS privatization or leased management could take place. The RB and LCU workshops are small units serving force account units, and could be restructured in parallel with the restructuring of these force account units. 1.22 In addition to the inadequacy of maintenance funding (para. 1.37), road infrastructure provision is hampered by poor budgetary planning and programming procedures, including limited capacity within MOW, the lack of a monitoring/evaluation and financial/fiscal performance control function, and weak project accounting. The crucial task of annual programming is currently being developed in the RB, through a comprehensive and operations-oriented, road network programming and maintenance management tool (Planning Management and Maintenance System-PMMS). This would provide a system flexible enough to define rolling plans and annual programs, pending capacity to update the road data base and users costs. This system is currently being extended to all parts of the network, and is expected to soon become available to all concerned agencies. 1.23 Accounting and financial management capacity is inadequate in both the RB and the LCU (mostly manual procedures, financial statements delayed and accounting records not kept up to date, no recording of fixed assets, weak accounting and contract monitoring of civil works, important control functions such as bank reconciliations not carried out, and lack of information for control and monitoring progress). The only significant exception concerns contracts financed under donor-funded projects, for which accounting and monitoring procedures are gradually being put in place. 1.24 Lesotho has adopted the SATCC guidelines harmonizing standards and specifications. However, there are no detailed design standards and standard specifications for all the various road classes and bridges. The LCU prepared a "Design Guidelines" handbook for low volume roads and a technical manual for labor-based contractors hired under training programs. This was further supported within the framework of the current IDA-financed Infrastructure Engineering Credit (IEP). In the RB, design standards and standard specifications vary from one project to the other depending on which consultants are contracted for design, which results in inconsistent standards and, eventually higher costs when roads need to be engineered to higher standards. The lack of complete design standards, standard specifications, and quality control procedures, results in undue complexity for RB and LCU to properly monitor
 - 9- consultants carrying out road works design and supervision. The RB intends to continue strengthening its Design Section, and design of rehabilitation works and surveys and bills of quantities for periodic maintenance on the RB unpaved roads will be carried out in house. However, the capacity for design of rehabilitation and upgrading works remains currently weak in MOW, and the few available qualified engineers are needed to take over more urgent tasks than engineering studies which can easily be carried out by outside consultants, provided that clear design methods and reporting guidelines are set in order to harmonize design and ensure comparability and consistency of feasibility and design studies. No quality assurance plans are included in works contracts and there are no specific quality control procedures, while field laboratories for material testing are insufficient. There are neither environmental guidelines for assessing road works impacts, except for those developed by LCU for low volume roads, nor any regulatory measures for stricter emission standards. The Network 1.25 The 5,200 km long national roads network is relatively extensive, particularly in economically active areas. About 2,000 kIn, managed by the RB and LHDA, are public ("gazetted") roads. Almost all RB and LHDA paved roads are classified as primary roads, while most RB and LCU gravel roads are classified as secondary and tertiary roads. Most earth roads, as well as roads transferred from CWS to LCU for upgrading to engineered standards, are unclassified. The road network is unbalanced in length and condition, particularly in the eastern mountainous region of the country. PROJECT BENEFITS 4.1 Substantial quantifiable and non-quantifiable economic benefits are expected from the project, and in particular: (i) alleviation of poverty; (ii) lower transport and vehicle operating costs; and (iii) reduction in road works costs from the increased competition associated with the development of a LRCI. The project is expected to impact positively a significantly large proportion of poor people, through the large amount of jobs created from labor-based works and increased access to basic services from upgrading and rehabilitating rural roads in isolated mountainous areas to all weather standards (para. 4.12). Increased freight and exchange of goods, in particular cattle raised in mountainous areas, could also result from improved access to district towns due to the upgrading and rehabilitation of key priority roads. Transport in general will benefit from the lower vehicle operating costs which will result from improved road conditions. In addition, much of the rehabilitation works of roads on the brink of severe deterioration will serve to preserve past investments from accelerated road deterioration, and substantial savings in future investment and vehicle operating costs are expected from the strengthening of road maintenance. The development of local contractors, besides its poverty reduction focus through the support to employment-generating labor-based contractors, aims at reducing costs with the increase in competition amongst contractors, and at enhancing efficiency of maintenance operations. The project will also strengthen the implementation capacity in the road sector through capacity building focusing on streamlining management and planning procedures. Systematic beneficiary assessments with road users and local officials, and local involvement in setting priority road upgrading works, will be used to maximize benefits. 4.2 The economic analysis for civil works on main roads is based upon the IEP- developed PMMS data base, after updating traffic estimates and unit costs, reducing the average traffic growth figure from the NTS projections of 6 to 7% for the next five years to a more realistic 4%, and entering road condition estimates for the LCU network. Revised road condition estimates for the gravel and earth roads network were also used. It assessed economic and financial costs, taxes and duties, and foreign and local percentages, and results are based on HDM (Highway Development Model) runs, which generally produced consistent results with the PMMS. The analysis has focused on ensuring that investments made are high priority, and rehabilitation and upgrading of major roads are all economically viable. No road reconstruction was found to have an
 - 50 - internal economic rate of return (IRR) higher than 12%. The PMMS and HDM analysis also determined appropriate maintenance options for the RB roads. 4.3 Concerning the upgrading of rural roads to all-weather standards by LCU, it was agreed with GOL that the analysis of LCU and CWS roads would not be based solely on a ranking of estimated ERRs to select the highest priority roads. This would not meet the key GOL objectives of poverty alleviation and opening access to mountainous areas. Instead, roads have been selected on the basis of both economic analysis (first year ERR and NPV/C values) weighted with prioritization criteria (population served, District Council priority ranking, and traffic thresholds). Those criteria have been agreed at negotiations (paras 3.5). Rehabilitation and maintenance of village roads will be selected on the basis of communities involvement and choice. IDA's role will be to ensure that criteria used are consistent, and that a network rationale is carried out in selecting roads. 4.4 Details of the economic analysis are included in the Implementation Manual, and are summarized in Annex N. The analysis will be updated annually as the program develops, in particular for the upgrading part of the program, and vehicle operating costs will be monitored during the project by establishing baseline data at the beginning of the project. 4.5 Upgrading Works (about 28 % of civil works base costs): the average IRR is about 121% for RB sections to be upgraded from gravel to paved standards, and the NPV/Coat ratio for upgrading LCU roads to engineered gravel standards is 0.7 overall. Guidelines will be agreed to ensure that comparisons between feasibility studies are possible. About 250 km out of a total of 416 km of CWS rural roads to be upgraded to engineered gravel standards currently have positive NPV/C values. 4.6 Rehabilitation Works (about 12 % of civil works base costs): the average IRR is about 49% for RB paved roads, confirming that rehabilitation is economically viable. Rehabilitation of RB gravel roads in poor condition shows an average IRR of 65%. Concerning LCU roads, Unit NPV ratios (NPV/km) average 0.025. 4.7 Periodic Maintenance Works (about 22 % of civil works base costs): IRRs average about 35 % for paved roads (ranging from 12 to 55 %), and 80% for gravel roads (ranging from 61 to 114%). 4.8 The sensitivity analysis, which was conducted with regard to traffic and discount rates, shows that roads included in the program qualify with a traffic growth rate as low as 2% and with a discount rate as high as 20%, with the exception of a few links. E. ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS 4.16 The project comprises rehabilitation and upgrading of existing roads, not construction of new roads, and direct environmental impacts should be minimal. The bulk of the upgrading works concerns rural roads, which will undergo works to be mostly carried out with labor intensive methods by small local contractors. Technical specifications have been reviewed and found acceptable. Indirect impacts, that would result if improving transport efficiency were to promote non-sustainable exploitation of valuable or fragile resources, and lead to resources depletion and degradation of important ecosystems, are expected to be negligible at the proposed levels of rehabilitation and/or improvement. Improved maintenance under the project will have a positive environmental impact. As no road realignment is envisaged, no resettlement is expected to take place. Hence from an environmental standpoint, the project has been classified in category "B". An Environment Analysis and Mitigation Plan has been prepared and is included in Annex P. 4.17 Although the Ministry does not have sufficient environmental assessment or management capacity at the present time, environmental concerns are handled by consulting engineers. Moreover, careful monitoring of resettlement issues will be carried out as part of the design studies for the upgrading of existing roads, which could result in minor realignments due to earthworks and widening. Final engineering design would include the necessary provisions to counteract both direct and indirect environmental and resettlement impacts, and also ensure that contract documents contain apprpriate measures to mitigate such adverse effects. Standard Terms of Reference, including specific environmental clauses, have been prepared for surveys, feasibility and design studies, and supervision. Standard bidding and contract documents to be used for all works will incorporate the recommendations of the study on the socio-environmental aspects of LCU road works, and include the necessary provisions to counteract both direct and indirect environmental impacts. Standard bidding and contract documents have been agreed at negotiations. 4.18 The project will support strengthening GOL environmental analysis and monitoring capacity in the roads sector. The fees (or road tariff) will consist of an access fee - road toll-gate fees, border fees/short-term SACU permits, license fees on motor vehicles and a supplementary heavy vehicle license fee, and fines on overloaded vehicles - and a user fee in the form of road maintenance levy collected on all transport fuels. General budget funds would be reserved for upgrading, improvement, and new construction. Since the above charges are not regular taxes, but fees-for-service, the proceeds from the road tariff will be deposited into a special fund which has been established as the Road Fund by Legal Notice No 179 of 1995 published in the Government Gazette. The regulations of the Road Fund have been gazetted in Legal Notice No 16 of 1996. The notice specifies the purpose of the special fund, its sources of revenues, and how the fund will be managed. It has been agreed that the Road Fund will be pro-actively managed by a representative board of management. The Board has been created within the framework of the Legal Notice No 16 of 1996, and is assisted by a full-time independent Secretariat which will manage the day-to-day affairs of the Road Fund, and monitor all revenues and expenditures on behalf of the Board. The Board reports to the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and will generally advise the Minister on all matters pertaining to the financing of roads. In the medium term (expected to be two years), based on experience with the Board, MOF would seek to bring forward legislation to turn the Board into an autonomous board managing the Road Fund in an executive capacity. Expenditures to be Financed Revenues from the Road Fund will primarily be used to finance routine and periodic maintenance and rehabilitation of the classified road network, together with maintenance of selected Village Councils roads, and selected road safety projects. Village Council roads include those under the jurisdiction of the Civil Works Section (CWS) of the Ministry of Local Government as well as roads where the Village Council agrees to make their contribution to maintenance through a cost sharing arrangement. Village Councils will be expected to contribute 50 percent towards the cost of maintaining Village Council roads, and may choose to do so by contributing direct labor. District Councils will be expected to contribute 50 percent towards the cost of maintaining urban roads using revenues from rates and other local taxes. Road fund revenues may be used to finance rehabilitation, but will only be used to finance road upgrading and new works, once all road maintenance requirements have been met. Source of Revenues Revenues will come from five main sources: (i) road toll-gate fees collected on all vehicles leaving Lesotho, including GOL vehicles; (ii) border fees/short-term SACU permits charged on all foreign trucks entering Lesotho; (iii) license fees on motor vehicles and a supplementary license fee collected from heavy vehicles to ensure they pay in full for the damage they do to the road pavement; (iv) fines on overloaded vehicles; and (v) a road maintenance levy added to the price of all transport fuels, including the fuel consumed by government.
 Annex C Lesotho cannot raise its fuel prices above those prevailing in South Africa and it attempts to keep the price of fuel at least 5 lisente below the South African level. Since the prices of petrol and diesel in Lesotho are currently 20 lisente and 12 lisente below those in South Africa, there is scope for adding a road user charge of 15 and 7 lisente respectively to the current price of petrol and diesel without reducing the relative margin between Lesotho and South Africa to less than 5 lisente. Although the relative prices between Lesotho and South Africa vary, the current differentials have been used to estimate the composition of the road maintenance levy. The Road Fund Board The Board consists of a chairman and eleven members who have been appointed by the Minister of Finance. Six members represent concerned government departments and five will represent non-governmental organizations. The government members have been nominated by their Principal Secretaries (Ministries of Finance, Economic Planning, Works, Transport & Communications, Local Government, and Natural Resources). The non-governmental members have been nominated by the organizations they represent (Chamber of Commerce and Industry; Bus and Mini-bus Association; Transport Association; Architects, Engineers and Surveyors Association; and Law Society). Additional non-voting members may be co-opted to the Board when required. Members of the Board are appointed for a period of two years and will be compensated for the time spent attending board meetings. Board meetings will be held at least once a month and will have four sub-comnmittees: Road Safety, Environment, Engineering, and Road Fees. Management of the Road Fund In general, funds from the Road Fund will only be disbursed for goods and services forming part of an approved maintenance program. Each check withdrawing funds from the road fund will be signed by two people: one from the Advisory Board and the other from MOF. Work undertaken by contractors will be certified by a registered engineer before payment is made. Road agencies will transmit requests for payment to the road fund secretariat (copy to MOF) who will arrange to pay the contractor directly out of the road fund account. Work undertaken by force account will be subject to similar financial controls. The Board will review the annual expenditure programs put forward by the various road agencies and decide, in light of these requests and in consultation with MOF, on the overall size of the road program to be financed through the road fund. Based on these revenue requirements, it will then recommend to MOF the required levels of the supplementary licenses and road maintenance levy. The Board will also recommend how the revenues from the road fund should be sub-divided between the various road agencies entitled to draw from the road fund, including those dealing with road safety. The Board will negotiate agency agreements with of the Department of Customs and Department of Transport and Traffic for collection of road toll-gate fees, border fees/short-term SACU permits, motor vehicle license fees and supplementary heavy vehicle license fees. The agreements will provide for fees to be directly deposited into a designated account at the Central Bank. The road maintenance levy (added to the price of fuel) will be collected by the oil companies in South Africa and paid directly into a designated account at the Central Bank. The accounts and other financial statements of the road fund will be audited annually by a firm of auditors selected by the Auditor General. The audited annual accounts, which will eventually include a Statement of Income, a Balance Sheet, and a Statement of Cash Flow, will be published within three months of the end of each financial year. The audit will include a full financial audit and a selective technical audit. The Board will also publish an annual report within six months of the end of each financial year, dealing generally with the policies and activities of the Board during the year, and including a copy of the audited accounts and the auditors report on the accounts.

However, cost-benefit analysis for upgrading rural roads does not show high economic returns, particularly in the mountainous areas, due to the currently low traffic volumes and the relatively higher cost of civil works. Ancillary benefits range from (i) improved transport and mobility to and between villages and population centers not currently connected to the overall road network, (ii) use of labor- based methods resulting in the creation of employment (iii) year-around access to basic services in areas which are now isolated during the rainy season; and (iv) stimulation of agricultural production in areas which had limited access prior to upgrading and lack of timely transport services. The direct benefits from rehabilitation and maintenance will be a reduction in vehicle operating costs (VOCs), which will, in turn, be translated into lower transport costs for the movement of people and products. Rehabilitation works tackle: (i) deferred periodic maintenance of gravel roads, which mainly affected those roads with AADTs ranging from 100 to 300; and (ii) strengthening selected heavy-trafficked paved trunk roads (with AADTs above 5,000) to avoid deterioration caused by heavy trucks from the RSA where the legal axle-load limit is 50% higher than in Lesotho. Road maintenance will prevent deterioration of the existing structures to continue, and avoid further increasing VOCs and cost of future rehabilitation. In addition, maintenance of rural roads, which is by nature labor intensive and will be carried out by small local contractors and village crews, will generate substantial employment opportunities and provide a steady income to many local inhabitants. Since project works will be spread widely throughout Lesotho, most parts of the country will benefit from the employment generated by the Project. Costs: The economic analysis includes routine and periodic maintenance costs at a level sufficient to ensure that estimated road-user savings from improved surfaces will indeed be realized. However, unit costs are relatively high due to terrain conditions, and due to cost of labor for labor intensive works such as maintenance. There is some uncertainty over those costs because few local contractors -who are to carry out the bulk of maintenance works- have been employed until now. Base costs for rehabilitation and upgrading works have been estimated from recent civil works contracts in the Roads Branch (RB) and Labor Construction Unit (LCU) estimates. Economic Viability: As mentioned above, economic viability differs widely for major roads and rural low-volume roads. Average daily traffic levels on most rural roads under consideration for upgrading are low at present, particularly in the Highlands which are priority targets for improving access. This is due primarily to the poor condition of roads. Therefore, a key variable in determining the required level of upgrading for the rural roads, and the economic viability thereof, is the assumed rate of traffic increase. Without an increase in traffic levels, substantial investments would not be viable. In order to maximize the likelihood that investment in rural roads upgrading will at least be viable, even if not always optimal, and to stretch available resources as far as possible, upgrading of gravel roads has been designed with regard to the minimum MOW 5-meter width standards, and 3.5- meter width for earth tracks being built under the Civil Works Section (CWS) program. Geometric design standards for roads to be rehabilitated will be kept to the original "as-built" standards. Upgrading of main gravel roads to paved standards includes widening to standard widths justified by the high traffic volumes. Based on minimal rehabilitation works and upgrading works adjusted to terrain and weather conditions, carefully assessed unit costs for all categories of works, and reasonable assumptions as to future traffic volumes, the analysis indicates that road works have an economic rate-of-return in excess of the estimated opportunity cost of capital (12%). It has been assumed in the base case that traffic will gradually increase at a moderate average rate of 4%.  Annex P LESOTHO ROAD REHABILITATION AND MAINTENANCE PROJECT ENVIRONMENTAL ANALYSIS AND MITIGATION EA Screening The Road Rehabilitation and Maintenance Project is in EA Category B which requires an environmental evaluation and mitigation plan under the Bank OD 4.01, Environmental Assessment. In lieu of national environmental assessment legislation which is being developed by the National Environmental Secretariat, Bank guidelines were used for the environmental analysis for this project. Bank missions discussed the development of EA legislation with the Environment Department in the Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources. The project focuses on rehabilitation, maintenance and upgrading of existing roads and no new roads will be constructed. Construction methods will employ labor intensive techniques using local labor and small contractors which is commonly utilized in Lesotho under the Local Construction Unit of the Ministry of Works (LCU). Negative environmental and social impacts due to the project are expected to be minimal because of the focus on rehabilitation and non-mechanized construction, hence the EA classification of Category B. The primary environmental concems consist of erosion control and avoidance of destruction of natural vegetation which may be rare or endangered in Lesotho. The primary social concems is disruption of travel due to construction and the potential for disturbing or taking of agricultural land as a result of construction. Environmental Analysis With funding by SIDA, the Ministry of Works contracted a Socioeconomic and Environmental Impact Analysis of the Local Construction Unit activities. The consultants were contracted locally. The analysis consisted of a meter by meter environmental inspection of 10% of the roads rehabilitated by the LCU and a survey of 496 households which wvere affected by the LCU road rehabilitation program. It was decided that this on-going work would satisfy Bank requirements for environmental analysis and that any further work would have been redundant. The analysis found that generally the road rehabilitation work was adequate and that environmental protection, while not a specific charge of the LCU, was routinely incorporated into design and contract documents. Most of the households expressed satisfaction with the work and only a small percentage felt that they lost land or amenities as a result of the road work. Surprisingly, only 11 of 496 households noted any problems with erosion. One more serious environmental point was the failure to restore borrow areas to a more useful condition. Far too often the borrow pits were simply abandoned causing hazards to humans and livestock.
 Annex P Conclusions and Recommendations The communities in the road corridors are ovenvhelmingly satisfied with the roads and the routes. The communities value the improved accessibility and decreased travel time more than the potential for commercial or economic development. The survey also shows that while the local construction policy is appreciated in the communities, the direct and indirect impacts have been minimal because of the limited number of households providing labor and the short duration. However, the survey does show that improved skills from the construction was highly regarded by respondents. It was also noted that the LCU employment was found to be very equitably distributed. Given the steep gradient topography, high rainfall and erodable soils, erosion in Lesotho is a natural part of the weathering process and would be quite severe without human habitation and use. Farming and overgrazing make the erosion rate more intolerable and there is great concern that road work does not unnecessarily contribute to more erosion. LCU roads tend to follow natural contours so that erosion is reduced and good drainage where possible keeps the losses to acceptable limits. However, the focus of the erosion control has been more on roadway protection and less on what happens to run off after it leaves the roadway. This lack of attention to off-road protection does cause erosion losses in field below the road and LCU must expand it's attention to more devices that will dissipate run-off energy as it leaves the road. The analysis did show that much of the environmental damage was due to a lack of, or deferred, maintenance rather than to inappropriate design, construction techniques or materials. The lack of systematic light maintenance leads to rapid deterioration of drainage structures which in turn increases the likelihood of erosion problems. A disquieting finding of the road inspection is that in several areas, vegetation had been unnecessarily trampled by the construction crews and trucks. In some cases, the vegetation included Aloe. One of the two species of Aloe in Lesotho is endemic to Lesotho and is an endangered species. The construction crews have to be better trained in respect to protecting natural vegetation. Mitigation LCU has recently constructed two training centers for staff and local contractors. Part of the training includes erosion control techniques. LCU has also agreed to review the Socio-economic and Environmental Report and incorporate the recommendations into the training program. As a result, LCU is likely to strengthen the components on erosion control. It is also likely that they will be able to add training material on restoration of borrow areas and include requirements for such restoration in their contract documents. LCU will seek assistance from the Environment Department of the Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources to include training components on recognition of valuable and endangered vegetation. Assurances for these recommended practices will be sought during negotiations. The most important aspect of mitigation for road rehabilitation work is to have on-site supervision and monitoring with respect to environmental concerns. LCU will continue to improve in this area through internal training at the training centers. The curriculum will be adjusted to include the materials recommended in the socioeconomic and environmental impact study. Supervision forms could also be amended to include certain environmental and social parameters for reporting from the field to headquarters.

doc.repnme: Lesotho - Road Rehabilitation and Maintenance Project
doc.abstracts: The primary objectives of the Road Rehabilitation and Maintenance Project are to support both continued economic growth and the government's poverty reduction strategy through: 1) developing the government capacity to regularly maintain the whole classified road network by the year 2000, and upgrade priority roads to improved serviceability standards; 2) improving access to isolated areas and basic services in district centers by facilitating road traffic, and lowering transport costs; 3) further developing the emerging private local road construction and maintenance industry, using mainly labor-based methods to generate productive employment; and 4) strengthening the planning, implementation and management capacity of the Road Sector agencies, through policy and institutional reforms and capacity building support. The project will finance three major components over the July 1996 to March 2001 period: 1) a civil works program focusing on maintenance, and including the rehabilitation of sections of the roads branch and labor construction unit network, and selected upgrading of selected priority roads; 2) design engineering and supervision services in support of the program; and 3) sector institutional reform and capacity building, including logistical support to the Ministry of Works.
